The outdoor spot seats more than 300 people who can eat at any of the three food trucks serving Mexican, American and Asian cuisine. By: Ella Rhoades Posted FORT MYERS, Fla. ‚Äî Bay Street Yard opened five days early in the heart of downtown Fort Myers. The outdoor spot seats more than 300 people who can eat at any of the three food trucks here serving Mexican, American and Asian cuisine. Bay Street Yard also has two bars and a stage for live entertainment. Co-owner David Fry says it's a place to socialize and be entertained. ‚ÄúWe want people to walk away saying this place is cool, and they really treated me well,‚Äù he said. The outdoor dining experience has a private VIP area upstairs, and it can also be rented. Bay Street Yard is closed Tuesdays and Wednesdays. Copyright 2024 Scripps Media, Inc. All rights reserved. LEARN MORE Our Impact The victories we‚Äôve achieved are possible because of people like you. From landmark campaigns that prevent Bay-fill to major restoration funding wins like Measure AA and pioneering the science and technology of wetlands restoration, your support drives our success. LEARN MORE Meet Our Team A shared passion for the environment and Bay Area brings together a dynamic and diverse group of individuals who work to drive progress and change. Get to know us and learn more about what we all do to save the Bay. LEARN MORE Work With Us Imagine waking up everyday knowing that you‚Äôre making a difference. With over a decade of experience in business development and fundraising, she has cultivated high-impact partnerships with Fortune 100 companies, led innovative revenue strategies, and raised millions to support nonprofit initiatives advancing equity and inclusion. A Bay Area native and passionate hiker, Christiana has a deep love for the outdoors and is committed to preserving the region‚Äôs unique ecosystems and natural resources that have shaped her connection to the environment. √ó Favorite native plant or animal: California Poppy Favorite thing to do around the Bay Area: Walking in the Presidio, spending time by the water, and catching San Francisco Giants games Superpower: Having difficult but productive conversations Carmela Krantz WOVEN Carmela moved to San Francisco right after college and has called it home ever since. She is drawn¬†to its diversity ‚Äì of people, places, and the stunning natural beauty of the Bay Area. An HR professional, she has spent most of her career working with startups and growing businesses. In 2017, she founded a human resources consulting firm, where she often applies her superpower: having difficult yet productive conversations that others tend to avoid. √ó Favorite native plant or animal: Red-tailed hawk Favorite thing to do around the Bay Area: Night hiking when there‚Äôs a meteor shower or a comet in the sky Superpower: The ability to shape-shift, so that I could soar like an eagle and dive like a Cuvier‚Äôs beaked whale Joy Leilei Shih-Casado Ko Olina Joy Leilei Shih-Casado is an ocean conservationist with a PhD in Oceanography from the University of Hawai ªi at MƒÅnoa, a masters in Marine Biodiversity and Conservation from Scripps Institution of Oceanography, and a bachelor‚Äôs in Astrophysics from UC Berkeley. Her research has focused on coral reefs in French Polynesia, Hawai ªi, and the Florida Keys, as well as invasive species, symbionts, and microbial nutrient cycling. She works actively on plastic pollution policy at the local, state, and national levels. She has served on the Executive Committees of the Surfrider Foundation and the Sierra Club in both California and Hawaii and currently chairs the Sierra Club National Marine Team. A master, resuce, and scientific diver, Joy enjoys freediving and hiking with her three dogs and family in her free time. √ó Favorite native plant or animal: Valley Oak ‚Äì it reflects an essential character of the Bay Area and provides me peace and inspiration Favorite thing to do around the Bay Area: Biking and hiking along the waterfront Superpower: Maintaining perspective and staying positive Diane Oshima City and Port of San Francisco Diane is a Bay Area native with a career in urban environmental planning and stewardship for the City and Port of San Francisco.¬† As the former Planning and Environment Director at the Port, she led community initiatives to develop the Port‚Äôs Waterfront Master Plan, along with diverse shoreline public access, and park and development projects serving San Francisco and the Bay Area. Passionate about fostering genuine community connections, Diane believes in learning together ‚Äì especially in the age of climate change ‚Äì to ensure the San Francisco Bay waterfront remains an invaluable public and environmental resource for all. √ó Favorite native plant or animal: Volunteer scrub oak ‚Äì years ago, one took root in our front yard, and it has been slowly growing into a majestic guardian of our home. Favorite thing to do in the Bay Area: Biking around Marin with my daughter in tow, discovering new routes and favorite spots. Superpower: The ability to stop time ‚Äì to learn, explore, and do all the things I‚Äôm curious about Adrienne Donley Unicycive Adrienne Donley serves as Vice President of People and Culture at Unicycive, bringing over 20 years of experience supporting life sciences companies in developing solutions that improve patients‚Äô lives. A Bay Area native, Adrienne has a lifelong passion for the outdoors and enjoys hiking the hills of Marin County with her husband and daughter. She is deeply committed to advancing scalable climate adaptation solutions and is honored to support Save The Bay‚Äôs mission. √ó Favorite native plant or animal: California Quail Favorite thing to do in the Bay Area: Being within sight, sound, or scent of the Bay‚Äîespecially when sailing, kayaking, or treading water Superpower: To solve problems and enhance lives through design and dialogue Nancy Fee Architectural Historian Nancy is a San Francisco native who returned to her hometown after earning a PhD in Art History from Columbia University. She is dedicated to ensuring that people of all backgrounds and from across the Bay Area can experience and enjoy the beauty of the Bay. √ó Favorite native plant or animal: Gray Fox‚Äîthe adorable resident of the Baylands Favorite thing to do in the Bay Area: Biking along the Bay Trail or walking at Palo Alto Baylands Nature Preserve‚Äîbut nothing beats a sunset sail near the Golden Gate Bridge Superpower: Healing‚Äîwhat could be more incredible than the power to heal Lauren Swezey Lauren is a Bay Area native who began her career as a journalist for Sunset Magazine, covering sustainable gardening and landscape design. Chris has been involved in conservation and environmental causes for over 20 years, and loves spending time on the Bay and shoreline. √ó Favorite native plant or animal: Valley Oaks‚Äîmy first memory of Northern California is their dusty green canopies on golden hillsides. Superpower: Levitation‚Äîthe ability to calmly lift my arms to the sky and float, soaring effortlessly through the air Dennis DeBroeck Retired Attorney & Conservation Advocate Dennis is a retired partner from Fenwick & West, where he provided strategic legal and business advice to startups and publicly traded companies. Dennis and his wife are avid hikers and passionate about exploring the regions culture and cuisine. √ó Favorite native plant or animal: Redwood trees Favorite thing to do around the Bay Area: Swimming in Aquatic¬†Park Superpower: Flying Peter Laidlaw J.P. Morgan Private Bank Peter works for the J.P. Morgan Private Bank, providing  investment and planning advice to wealthy families. Originally from the East Coast, he has called the Bay Area home for over a decade and is committed to preserving and protecting the ecosystems and natural resources. He is proud to continue the legacy of his wife‚Äôs family, who have been dedicated conservationists in the region for over 100 years, and to instill an appreciation for California‚Äôs beauty in his two young children. √ó Favorite native plant or animal: Lupine (good in nature and hopefully the home garden too) Favorite thing to do around the Bay Area: Anything close to the water! Hiking, sailing, or anything outdoors Superpower: Predicting the Bay Area weather? Or teleportation, it would make commuting a lot easier Hugh Le PwC Hugh Le is a Partner at PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) Strategy&, focusing on corporate strategy and energy transition. He helps companies address climate resiliency, sustainability, and enterprise transformations. He is passionate about protecting our Bay and bringing together solutions across business, policy, education, and individual change. He is serving Save The Bay so that our Bay can be enjoyed by future generations. √ó Storm Drain Master Plan Cities should create storm drain master plans that identify areas at risk of flooding due to current and future storms and identify projects to ensure the storm drain system has the capacity to function under future conditions. Identified projects should be prioritized based on future flood risk, water quality, and benefits to disadvantaged communities. As much as possible, the city should identify green stormwater infrastructure solutions to drainage issues; this could take the form of a green streets master plan. Examples Pacifica Pacifica‚Äôs Storm Drain Master Plan identifies capacity deficiencies in the storm drainage system, develops feasible alternatives to correct these deficiencies, and plans the infrastructure that will serve future development. It includes an analysis of future precipitation impacts on the storm drain system. San Mateo County The San Mateo Countywide Green Streets Master Plan identifies ‚Äúhow and where to build sustainable streets in San Mateo County that integrate stormwater management with local priorities, like bike and pedestrian mobility, transit improvements, climate change adaptation, and more.‚Äù It includes an analysis of stormwater runoff under future climate scenarios, which determined that the planned green street projects could offset the projected roadway runoff due to climate change for a 2-year storm. Additionally, the green streets projects were prioritized based on water quality, flood risk, water supply, climate change impacts, groundwater constraints, utility constraints, vulnerable community indicators, vehicle ownership statistics, urban canopy, and urban heat island effect. √ó Integrating Flood Resilience Into Capital Improvement Planning Local jurisdictions must ensure that public infrastructure (such as parks, streets, sewers, stormwater infrastructure, and shoreline infrastructure) are designed for flood resilience and incorporate nature-based solutions wherever possible. They can do this by creating capital improvement planning processes to ensure all proposed projects are evaluated for flood resilience and green infrastructure potential. Examples Burlingame Burlingame has a green infrastructure checklist used to evaluate opportunities to include green stormwater infrastructure (GSI) features in capital projects. This approach ensures that no opportunities for GSI are missed. It can be found in Appendix B of the city‚Äôs Green Infrastructure Plan . San Francisco San Francisco has a ‚ÄúGuidance for Incorporating Sea Level Rise into Capital Planning in San Francisco Sea Level Rise Checklist‚Äù . Using this checklist ensures that all capital projects planned in the sea level rise vulnerability zone are resilient to sea level rise. √ó Sea Level Rise and Groundwater Rise Overlay Districts Sea level rise and groundwater rise overlay districts map out which geographical areas will be affected by flooding under future climate conditions and apply specific development requirements or restrictions on those areas. Overlay districts can be created through a zoning code update and are a key step in ensuring that flood-resilient development conditions are implemented and enforced. OneShoreline‚Äôs Planning Policy Guidance provides template language for creating Sea Level Rise and Groundwater Rise Overlay Districts. Examples Burlingame In 2021, Burlingame updated its zoning ordinance to include regulations for the Bayfront Commercial District, including guidelines for new development to be resilient to sea level rise. Section 25.12.050 outlines public access, flood, and sea level rise performance guidelines for new developments. It adopts Burlingame‚Äôs Map of Future Conditions, including a Sea Level Rise Overlay District, which is based on the Our Coast Our Future hazard map . South San Francisco In 2022, South San Francisco (SSF) updated its zoning code to include a Flood Plain/Sea Level Rise overlay district. The overlay district includes areas that will flood under a 36-inch sea level rise scenario and a 100-year storm. It imposes new construction requirements including base flood elevations sufficient to protect against the FEMA 100-year event with 3 feet of sea level rise, nature-based stormwater infrastructure designed to function under future conditions, and a bay access buffer within 100 ft from the shoreline. √ó Shoreline Resilience Plan With the passage of SB 272 (Laird, 2014), Bay Area cities are required to create Shoreline Resilience Adaptation Plans (RSAPs) and have those plans approved by the Bay Conservation and Development Commission (BCDC) by 2034. BCDC has released draft RSAP guidelines which cities must follow when creating their shoreline plans. The guidelines will be finalized at the end of 2024. We hope to see the final guidelines reinforce an emphasis on nature-based solutions, public access, and community engagement. Examples Hayward The Hayward Regional Shoreline Adaptation Master Plan (HRSAP) was created in 2021 to establish a vision and adaptation strategies for protecting natural and built shoreline assets from sea level rise. It recommends shoreline resilience projects such as horizontal levees, gently sloping vegetated buffers that provide sea level rise protection and water quality benefits. The HRSAP was created by a joint powers authority consisting of the City, the Hayward Area Park and Recreation District (HARD), and the East Bay Regional Park District. √ó Favorite native plant or animal: Sky Lupine Favorite thing to do around the Bay Area: Reading a book outdoors and spending time among redwoods Superpower: Telekinesis Erin Pang Policy Manager epang@savesfbay.org Having grown up in the Bay Area, Erin is excited to join Save The Bay and work towards equitable climate policies for the region. Her previous experience includes advocating for renewable energy policy at Environment New Mexico and working on California local government outreach and engagement programs at SGA Marketing. Outside of work, she enjoys reading, painting, and being outdoors. √ó Favorite native plant or animal: When the poppies are blooming Favorite thing to do around the Bay Area: Hiking and taking advantage of the variety of landscapes around the Bay Area Superpower: Shapeshifting! You could be a bird one day and a sea lion another Josh Quigley Policy Manager jquigley@savesfbay.org Josh is the Policy Manager for Save The Bay working to secure funding to restore Bay wetlands and enact regulations to restrict pollution and promote climate adaptation. Prior to joining Save The Bay, Josh worked as a federal legislative staffer for both the U.S. Senate and House of Representatives. √ó Favorite native plant or animal: Bull kelp Favorite thing to do around the Bay Area: Swimming or surfing along the shoreline Superpower: Ability to nap the moment she finds a sunbeam Laura Walsh Policy Manager lwalsh@savesfbay.org Laura studied sea level rise at the Scripps Institution of Oceanography and has been working in climate resilience and water management for ten years. √ó Favorite native plant or animal: California giant salamander Favorite thing to do around the Bay Area: Exploring my neighborhood on my bike Superpower: Breathing underwater Miriam Lucking Restoration Operations Specialist mlucking@savesfbay.org Mimi (she/her) grew up in Seattle, Washington before attending Mills College, where she studied Biology with a concentration in Ecology, Evolution and Behavior. She has spent time in outdoor education teaching students at San Mateo Outdoor Education, as well as in restoration serving on a Washington Conservation Corps crew restoring salmon habitat. She has also dabbled in organic farming and animal behavior research and she is passionate about preserving ecosystems and building climate resilience. √ó Favorite native plant or animal: There are so many, but the CA Buckeye‚Äôs come to mind. They are the first to unfurl their 5-finger leaves in late winter, a reminder that spring and longer days are on its way, and the last to drop their buckeyes in fall, a reminder to rest. Favorite thing to do around the Bay Area: Seasonal wildflower/berry hunting and tidepooling Superpower: The ability to make time pause while I take a nap or just lay to rest Meg Kikkeri Native Plant Nursery Assistant mkikkeri@savesfbay.org Meg (they/them) is the Native Plant Nursery Assistant. √ó Favorite native plant or animal: Sticky Monkey Flower ( Diplacus aurantiacus ) Favorite thing to do around the Bay Area: Rock climb and mountain bike on the East Bay trails Superpower: The ability to snap my fingers and be anywhere Melody Settelmayer Director of Communications msettelmayer@savesfbay.org Melody is a communications professional with more than a decade of experience working for environmental nonprofits. She moved to the Bay Area from Arcata, CA for college and has been here ever since. In her spare time, she can be found exploring hiking trails and climbing spots near and far. She earned a B.A. in US History from the University of California, Berkeley and resides in Oakland with two friendly rescue cats and a rapidly expanding indoor jungle. √ó Favorite native plant or animal: Poppies! Favorite thing to do around the Bay Area: Watch the sunset from the Berkeley hills Superpower: Speak every language (animal and human) AmyBeth Willis Political Organizer awillis@savesfbay.org AmyBeth (she/her) is a Political Organizer at Save the Bay, where she focuses on nurturing partnerships with coalitions and community organizations working on green stormwater infrastructure, affordable housing, and toxic sites impacted by sea level and groundwater rise. Her background is in faith-based organizing for immigrant rights alongside undocumented communities in Southern Arizona. She believes undoing oppressive systems requires all of us, and that we must prioritize the concerns of marginalized communities at the front lines of environmental issues. In her free time, she loves to sing, hike, and hang out with her cat Rosy. √ó Favorite native plant or animal: Harbor Porpoise ‚Äì a recovery story directly in line with Save The Bay‚Äôs work! Better water quality is one of the contributing factors. Favorite thing to do around the Bay Area: Spotting birds while swimming in the Bay Superpower: Being a Babel Fish ‚Äì able to understand the communication of all beings Masha Gutkin Director of Individual Giving mgutkin@savesfbay.org Masha is a strategic leader, fundraiser, and storyteller whose experience was forged building successful community-based initiatives. She is passionate about working with people to put their values into action. Born in the Soviet Union, Masha came to the United States as a refugee. Prior to Save The Bay, her career was mainly in human services, particularly fundraising for refugee resettlement and community-building led by and for former refugees. She is a Certified California Naturalist, a Master Birder in training, and enjoys swimming in, birding on and around, and rowing on the Bay. √ó Favorite native plant or animal: Sticky Monkey Flower Favorite thing to do around the Bay Area: Explore new hiking trails in all nine Bay Area counties with my dog, Klondike Superpower: Control the Weather Gwendolyn Tornatore Chief Advancement Officer gtornatore@savesfbay.org Gwendolyn‚Äôs passion for mission-driven work is everlasting. She is a visionary, where strategy, creativity and passion are the hallmarks of her 25-year career in fundraising and communications. She values and invests in building a collaborative team environment that develops farseeing strategies, effective organizational structures, and impactful results. In her spare time, mountain trails and ridge lines are where she roams with her family and their dog, Klondike. √ó AstraZeneca Toxic Site Groundwater and sea level rise threaten vulnerable communities by displacing toxic contamination. Richmond, CA, San Francisco Business Times The Issue The AstraZeneca site on the Richmond shoreline was once the site of sulfuric acid, pesticide, and fertilizer manufacturing. Because of this industrial pollution, it is now contaminated with high levels of toxins such as benzene, lead, arsenic, uranium, and pesticides like DDT. So far, cleanup efforts have included leaving contaminated soil on site and ‚Äúcapping‚Äù it by placing concrete on top. The City of Richmond has plans to build up to 4,000 housing units on top of this contaminated land. However, as sea levels rise, groundwater will also be pushed up to the surface, potentially pushing the toxins into pipes and through cracked concrete, putting the health of residents and surrounding communities at risk. The Solution For decades, frontline community members in Richmond have been raising awareness about the health and environmental threats posed by groundwater and sea level rise displacing toxic contaminants on industrial sites. Because of a long history of racist policies, the communities surrounding these sites are largely low-income communities of color. They are advocating for full cleanup of the AstraZeneca site before any housing is built on it, rather than simply capping contamination in place. This would involve removing all contamination from the site and taking it to a safer storage or treatment site. The Department of Toxic Substances Control (DTSC), which oversees cleanup of the site, should require AstraZeneca to conduct a full cleanup.¬†Additionally, groundwater and sea level rise should be considered in all toxic site cleanup efforts. Community Advocates Richmond Shoreline Alliance (Sunflower Alliance, Greenaction, Sierra Club, CESP, Point Molate Alliance, Richmond Progressive Alliance) √ó Favorite native plant or animal: CA Quail, I love the way they walk as their little head plumes bop around Favorite thing to do around the Bay Area: CA Bay Laurel, the leaves smell amazing Superpower: Immortality, there is so much to see and do in this world, and I would probably try a lot of things if I didn‚Äôt have to worry about dying üòé Hillary Kantmann Office and Technology Manager hkantmann@savesfbay.org Hillary is an administrative generalist with a wide range of professional experience. She‚Äôs had many fun and interesting jobs, including harvesting walnuts, running a woodshop, and sculpting giant props for parade floats, but especially enjoys work that benefits her community in some way. When not working, she spends time gardening, cooking, working on crafts or repair projects, and seeing live music. √ó Highway 37 Highway 37 will soon be underwater. The highway‚Äôs redesign, if done correctly, offers an opportunity to build climate-resilient infrastructure and restore 20,000 acres of wetlands. Highway 37 on a dry day, Karl Nielsen The Issue Highway 37 sits on a levee in San Pablo Bay in the north Bay Area.¬† In 2017, the highway was shut down for a month due to flooding caused by a combination of King Tides and winter storms. During the atmospheric rivers in January 2023, the highway was again closed for a weekend when it flooded due to Novato Creek overflowing. These closures will likely happen again and again as sea levels rise if no action is taken. This would disrupt 40,000 daily car trips which people depend on to get them to jobs in Marin, Sonoma, Napa and Solano Counties. Additionally, the levee that the highway sits on currently blocks natural tide flow from San Pablo Bay to wetlands on the north side of the highway. The Solution The redesign of Highway 37 is currently in the early planning stages. One of the proposed designs is to build the highway on an elevated causeway. This would put the highway above the reach of rising sea levels while also letting water ebb and flow with natural tidal action between San Pablo Bay and the wetlands beyond the highway. Once these 20,000 acres of wetlands are reconnected with the natural flow of tides, they can be restored to their full function, providing habitat, carbon sequestration, and flood resilience benefits. Photo: Sonoma Land Trust The Partners SR 37 Baylands Group (Audubon California, California Department of Fish and Wildlife, Ducks Unlimited Inc., Marin Audubon, Marin Conservation League, Point Blue Conservation Science, San Francisco Bay Joint Venture, San Francisco Bay Regional Water Quality Control Board, . San Francisco Estuary Institute, . San Pablo Bay National Wildlife Refuge, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Save The Bay, Sonoma Land Trust, . State Coastal Conservancy) √ó San Mateo County Of all the counties in California, San Mateo County is the most vulnerable to sea level rise. San Mateo, January 2, 2023, Bruce Washburn The Issues Sea Level Rise Sea levels could rise by up to 3.3 feet in San Mateo County by 2070 and 6 feet by 2100 according to the county‚Äôs Sea Level Rise Vulnerability Assessment . While the whole Bay Area will experience rising seas, San Mateo County is particularly vulnerable, with over 30,000 homes, dozens of schools and hospitals, and over 7,000 acres of wetlands at risk of flooding by 2070. Historically underinvested communities will be the most at risk when flooding occurs because historic inequities placed affordable housing in higher flood risk areas and because they are more vulnerable to economic damages incurred. Inland Flooding Not all flooding happens at the coast. As storms and groundwater rise become more extreme, Bay Area communities will continue to be impacted by flooded streets and homes due to outdated stormwater infrastructure. Additionally, urban areas are primarily covered in concrete, asphalt, and other surfaces that don‚Äôt allow water to seep through. This means that during storms, rainwater runs off these surfaces picking up pollutants (like motor oil, chemicals, and trash) on its way to creeks and the Bay. The Solutions Sea Level Rise Preparing the county for sea level rise will require a coordinated effort among cities to plan and implement solutions such as wetland restoration, horizontal levees, and sea walls. San Mateo County has taken steps in this direction with the creation of OneShoreline , a government agency that works across jurisdictional boundaries to plan and implement sea level rise resilience measures in the county. The County also conducted a countywide Sea Level Rise Vulnerability Assessment to identify areas that will be impacted by flooding and erosion and provide solutions. This coordinated effort should be replicated across the Bay Area. Cooperation between cities and counties throughout the Bay Area is necessary to ensure that shoreline protection in one area doesn‚Äôt result in greater flooding in others. This could happen, for example, when a sea wall in one city deflects storm surges towards an adjacent city without flood protections. There should also be coordination at the state and federal level to provide funding to low-income cities that may not otherwise have resources for sea level rise planning. The San Francisco Bay Conservation and Development Commission (BCDC) is currently creating guidelines to shape local sea level rise plans. Inland Flooding Cities must invest in updated stormwater infrastructure to reduce flooding and capture and clean stormwater before it reaches our waterways. In particular, green stormwater infrastructure (GSI) uses natural systems like vegetation, soil, and permeable surfaces to capture stormwater and filter out pollutants. Examples include rain gardens, bioswales, and tree wells. When cities upgrade streets, parks, and other infrastructure, they could be incorporating GSI at the same time, making these new investments more flood resilient.¬† San Mateo County is supporting this kind of integrated planning with their Sustainable Streets Master Plan . Bay Street Yard opens downtown Fort Myers with food trucks, concerts News Cape Coral Sports Opinion Restaurants Advertise Obituaries eNewspaper Legals LOCAL Upscale and urban-chic: New outdoor venue hits Fort Myers with concerts, food trucks Charles Runnells Fort Myers News-Press An '"urban-chic" oasis in downtown Fort Myers. That‚Äôs how the owners of Bay Street Yard describe their new outdoor entertainment venue on Bay Street ‚Äï now opening Saturday, nearly a week earlier than previously announced. Actually, it was always the plan to open this weekend, says co-owner David Fry. They wanted to give themselves a one-week cushion, just in case they didn't have everything ready in time. "We really don't want to miss Memorial Day weekend if we can help it," says Fry, a real-estate developer and former CEO of golf-club developer WCI Communities. "It's a busy weekend. We think ‚Äï we THINK ‚Äï Saturday night here there's gonna be a line down the street. I hope I'm right." Fry and his business partner ‚Äï former Fort Myers mayor Randy Henderson ‚Äï think they have something unique in Southwest Florida: A laid-back, outdoor venue that will be home to food trucks, yard games, live music, sports-watching parties on a huge LED screen and two bars built inside metal shipping containers. Fry calls the new venue "casual, but upscale." It‚Äôs inherently casual, he says, because it's outdoors. But just about everything else about Bay Street Yard is upscale and high-class. General Manager Mimi Wallace echoes that point. "There is nothing else around that is anything like this," she says. Bay Street Yard: Something 'new and exciting' in downtown Fort Myers On this recent Wednesday, Wallace and Bay Street Yard's owners sit on comfy couches in the venue's second-floor VIP area, The Loft, as they excitedly talk about their new venture. The covered, open-air Loft features three cozy "rooms" and a line of chairs along the balcony rail overlooking the main floor and concert stage below. All around them, Bay Street Yard employees in khaki shorts and orange shirts busily scurry around as they prepare for a private party. Wallace previously worked at JW Marriott Marco Island Beach Resort , but she says she eagerly took this new job as general manager of Bay Street Yard. "Once I saw they were creating this amazing concept, I knew I had to be a part of it," Wallace says. "It's creating something that is new and exciting." Since COVID, outdoor venues have been much more in demand, Fry says. And he knew that whatever he built in Fort Myers would lean into that outdoor concept. "It all came from the idea that people generally like being outside," Fry says. "When you go to a restaurants and the weather's nice, there's a waiting list to be outside. And that started me thinking." That's why everything at Bay Street Yard is open-air: Not so great in the summer, they admit, but something that will be huge draw once the weather cools. "During the winter, this place is going to be very popular," Fry predicts on this sweltering Wednesday afternoon. "A day like today? Some will come, some won't. Because it's hot." Collaborating with Luminary Hotel and a former Fort Myers mayor The outdoor entertainment venue was built on an empty lot owned by Henderson, just across from Luminary Hotel on Bay Street. Henderson says he's owned the land for 27 years. Fry was originally looking elsewhere to build the place, but then he started talking to the former Fort Myers mayor. They've been working together on the project for more than two years, Henderson says. Together, they've packed a lot into that 12,000-square-foot lot: Roughly eight steel shipping containers ‚Äï 20 feet long and painted orange and black ‚Äï converted into two bars, a manager's office, bathrooms and more; a concert stage; the upstairs VIP area; a food-truck lot with three food trucks; and a "play yard" with Adirondack chairs, artificial grass, a cornhole game, table tennis and more. "Every inch of it is being used," Wallace says. "Every single inch." Bay Street Yard's approximately 30 employees have been training for about a month to offer knowledgeable, attentive service, Wallace says. They're all employed by Mainsail Lodging & Development , the same company that owns the next-door Luminary Hotel. Mainsail was contracted to manage the place, Fry says. 'Permanent' food trucks and two bars One thing that sets apart Bay Street Yard is the three food trucks parked in the venue's paved food truck area. They're a permanent part of the place ‚Äï at least for the length of their one-year contract. Southwest Florida catering company Paradise Hospitality Group created the new food trucks just for Bay Street Yard, Wallace says. "They custom-built these trucks for us." The lineup features Banzai Asian Cuisine (Asian food), Bay Street Butcher (American food) and Rick's Taco Cartel (Mexican food). They offer everything from fried sushi rolls and Korean fried-chicken sandwiches to cheesesteak melts and smashburgers to shredded-beef tacos and churros in chocolate sauce. "It's better than any restaurant in downtown Fort Myers," Wallace says. "It's amazing." Paradise Hospitality's chefs include one trained by The Culinary Institute of America, Fry says. "These are not your normal food trucks. That's the point." To see the food truck's menus, visit baystreetyard.com/menu . Live bands, sports planned at Bay Street Yard The centerpiece of Bay Steet Yard is its 20-foot-wide, 10-foot-deep stage at the west end of the play yard. The covered stage is flanked by two big, colorful murals from local artist Shari Shifrin of the Fort Myers Mural Society . There's also a huge 8-foot tall, 13-foot wide LED TV screen for watching sports and other events. Wallace envisions themed TV-watching parties for the Super Bowl, the Final Four, golf tournaments and other major sports events ‚Äì all with a crystal-clear picture and a high-end sound system. As for live music, Bay Street Yard will bring in Florida and touring bands every Friday and Saturday night until 9:30 p.m., when deejays will keep the music going until 2 a.m., Wallace says. "We'll be bringing in the most spectacular live music performances from all over Florida," she says. That includes jazz, country, rock, classical and other genres ‚Äï starting Saturday with Nashville rock and country singer-songwriter Karin James and her band. "We have two criterias for entertainment," Fry says. "One is we're trying to make it unique. We want to make it unique in some fashion ‚Äï especially unique to downtown Fort Myers. "And then we want them to be sophisticated. We're not gonna have guys who come in here and use profane language on the stage. That's not gonna be allowed." Most of the bands are touring acts from Florida, but some will come from as far away as Nashville and New York. Wallace also expects to host events related to concerts happening at the nearby Caloosa Sound Amphitheater, such as meet-and-greets with major touring acts or private acoustic sets before or after their Caloosa Sound shows. For a lineup of upcoming bands, visit baystreetyard.com/specials-events . More about Bay Street Yard Bay Street Yard can be found next to the parking garage at 2136 Bay St. in downtown Fort Myers. It's across the street from Luminary Hotel. The new venue can accommodate 300-450 people. There isn't a rental fee for the VIP spaces in The Loft, but there is a "beverage minimum" purchase that depends on the day or the week and time of year. Prices start at $240 for eight people on weekdays (which breaks down to $30 per person), Wallace says. For more information and for concert and event updates, visit BayStreetYard.com or follow along on Facebook and Instagram . ‚Äî Charles Runnells is an arts and entertainment reporter for The News-Press and the Naples Daily News. To reach him, call 239-335-0368 (for tickets to shows, call the venue) or email him at crunnells@gannett.com . Follow or message him on social media: Facebook ( facebook.com/charles.runnells.7 ), X (formerly Twitter) ( @charlesrunnells ), Threads (@crunnells1) and Instagram ( @crunnells1 ). The two-story hub poured its first drinks Memorial Day weekend and had a ribbon cutting ceremony shortly after. It offers live entertainment, tasty bites and artisan styled cocktails in an open-air setting. ‚ÄúWe are really excited to be here and officially open! This is very unique, and the city has never seen anything like this before. It was created with a great team and brought in over 1,500 people on our soft opening,‚Äù said David Fry, Co-owner of Bay Street Yard. ‚ÄúThis is a great addition to Fort Myers. Successful businesses bring two things: providing the community with services and employment to people,‚Äù said Kevin Anderson, Mayor of Fort Myers. Bay Street Yard is located at 2136 Bay Street and is open Thursday through Monday. Its layout is unique because it is built with repurposed shipping containers, which create a sleek and modern style. The 12,000-square-foot venue features seating for over 300 people and holds over 450. It is fully equipped with two covered bars and three food trucks. COURTESY PHOTOS The trucks offer street-style fares from Bonzai Asian Cuisine, Rick‚Äôs Taco Cartel and Bay Street Butcher. Rafael Feliciano and Paradise Hospitality Group created the cuisine. The three food trucks were developed for Bay Street Yard. The menus include nachos, tacos, smash burgers, glizzies (also known as hotdogs), fried sushi baskets, dumplings and other delights. ‚ÄúWe are so fortunate to be a part of this and serve the food items we created. We focus on food trucks and catering, kitchens on wheels. These trucks are numbers seven, eight and nine for us in Fort Myers. Our culinary team brings a lot of flavors and expertise within different types of food and styles,‚Äù said Feliciano. Bay Street Yard has 12 specialty beverages, including top-shelf liquors, beers, wines, zero-proof creations and Happy Hour deals. ‚ÄúMocktails usually mean fruit punch, but we use non-alcoholic spirits to make tasteful drinks,‚Äù said Fry. ‚ÄúThey created a drink for me, called the ‚ÄòMimi Style 75.‚Äô It even has my favorite thing ‚Äì gold glitter,‚Äù said Mimi Wallace, General Manager. ‚ÄúWe have a cocktail selection like no other, and I could eat the Sunrise Smash Burger for breakfast, lunch and dinner.‚Äù ‚ÄúI am so thrilled to be a part of Bay Street Yard. We emphasize having fabulous service and had a record high in sales during our first night of opening. We had a line around the block to come in. This is a place for everyone. Bring the family and dog during the day and welcome everyone 21 and up to hang out at night,‚Äù said Wallace. Bay Street‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Loft‚Äù offers a wheelchair accessible VIP section with an elevator, providing convenient access for all guests. This versatile space can be rented entirely or divided into three private areas, accommodating small and large groups. The venue and upper-level space plan to serve the community with customizable events, including specialty catered menus and wine pairings for fundraisers, corporate functions, weddings, and more. Bay Street Yard was designed with the community in mind. The new social scene has a covered stage for live entertainment with sonic brilliance-produced sound systems, 8-foot by 13-foot LED televisions, and outdoor games of cornhole, ping pong and bocce. ‚ÄúImagine the Super Bowl here. I plan on playing movies during the holidays. I imagine kids on the lawn watching ‚ÄòPolar Express‚Äô and the adults sitting back and hanging out near the bar area,‚Äù said Fry. ‚ÄúI had an idea for a food truck and beer garden in downtown,‚Äù said Randy Henderson, Co-Owner and former mayor of Fort Myers. ‚ÄúTwo years later, here we are!
